title: Sumner Ely Wetmore Kittelle
text:
Sumner Ely Wetmore Kittelle (June 14, 1867 – December 29, 1950) was a <a href="rear%20admiral">rear admiral</a> in the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> and a veteran of the <a href="Spanish%E2%80%93American%20War">Spanish–American War</a> and <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>. He was also the third military <a href="Governor%20of%20the%20United%20States%20Virgin%20Islands">Governor of the United States Virgin Islands</a>. Late in life, he also became an author and published a book on his family's <a href="genealogy">genealogy</a>.
Kittelle was born in <a href="Peekskill%2C%20New%20York">Peekskill, New York</a>. He graduated from the <a href="United%20States%20Naval%20Academy">United States Naval Academy</a> in 1889. He was awarded the <a href="Navy%20Cross%20%28United%20States%29">Navy Cross</a> for his service during World War I, as commander of the battleship of the Atlantic Fleet. He was promoted to rear admiral in 1921 and made Governor of the Virgin Islands, a position he held only until 1922. Almost immediately on becoming governor, he sacked the civilian colonial assembly. In 1927, while a <a href="commandant">commandant</a> of the <a href="16th%20Naval%20District">16th Naval District</a>, he exposed a plot by "<a href="communists">communists</a>" to destroy a shipyard at <a href="Cavite">Cavite</a>. He retired in 1931.
In 1946, Kittelle wrote "The Ketel family,: Also (Ketele, Kettele, Kettel, Kittelle and Kittle)", a history of his family tree.
